paraphrased_statement: THE LINE is envisioned as a 170-kilometre, car-free linear city enclosed in a mirrored structure around 500 metres high and about 200 metres wide. Up to nine million residents are meant to live in vertically stacked neighbourhoods powered entirely by renewable energy, with daily needs reachable within a short walk and the surrounding desert largely preserved as a nature reserve.

source.source_title: THE LINE: a revolution in urban living

quoted_persons.name: Mohammed bin Salman
quoted_persons.role: Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia; initiator of NEOM and THE LINE

project_name: THE LINE, NEOM

originators.name: Mohammed bin Salman
originators.organization: Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, NEOM Company

related_research.title: Cognitive Cities: A journey to intelligent urbanism
related_research.notes: Frames cognitive cities as sentient, AI-driven urban systems; frequently linked to NEOM as a flagship example.

paraphrased_statement: A smart city is described as using real-time information to manage services, whereas a cognitive city is framed as a data-centric community that learns over time, builds memories and retrieves past experiences so it can act proactively and predictively, aiming to give residents back time and reduce everyday friction.

source.source_title: Cognitive City vs Smart City

project_name: NEOM Cognitive City and cognitive-city model

originators.name: Joseph Bradley
originators.role: Technology leader and public advocate of cognitive cities

related_research.title: Cognitive Cities: A journey to intelligent urbanism
related_research.notes: Defines cognitive cities as sentient urban systems that go beyond traditional smart-city infrastructure.

related_research.title: Towards Cognitive Cities: Advances in Cognitive Computing and its Application to Smart Cities
related_research.notes: Introduces the cognitive city concept and its main building blocks in an academic context.

related_research.title: Cognitive smart cities: Challenges and trending solutions
related_research.notes: Analyzes challenges and solution patterns for implementing cognitive smart cities.

paraphrased_statement: The MACeIP platform proposes a smart city architecture where dense IoT sensor networks, edge and cloud computing, and multimodal AI work together to form a responsive urban ecosystem. Interactive hubs, intelligent public asset management, pedestrian monitoring and a city-planning portal are combined so that the city can continuously sense conditions, analyse them and adapt services in near real time.

source.source_title: MACeIP: A Multimodal Ambient Context-enriched Intelligence Platform in Smart Cities

project_name: MACeIP: Multimodal Ambient Context-enriched Intelligence Platform

originators.name: Truong Thanh Hung Nguyen
originators.organization: Analytics Everywhere Lab, University of New Brunswick

originators.name: Phuc Truong Loc Nguyen
originators.organization: Analytics Everywhere Lab, University of New Brunswick

originators.name: Hung Cao
originators.organization: Analytics Everywhere Lab, University of New Brunswick

related_research.title: MACeIP: A Multimodal Ambient Context-enriched Intelligence Platform in Smart Cities
related_research.institution: Analytics Everywhere Lab, University of New Brunswick; RMIT University
related_research.notes: Presents MACeIP architecture, interactive hubs, sensor network and deployment in Canadian cities, focusing on Fredericton.

paraphrased_statement: A comprehensive review of artificial intelligence in smart cities argues that AI will underpin six core urban domains—governance, economy, mobility, environment, living and people. The vision is that data-driven AI systems will optimise transport, energy, environmental monitoring, public administration and citizen services, but that responsible deployment, inclusiveness and citizen engagement are crucial to avoid new barriers and risks.

source.source_title: Artificial Intelligence in Smart Cities—Applications, Barriers, and Future Directions: A Review

project_name: AI in Smart Cities literature review (Smart Cities journal)

institutions.name: Silesian University of Technology
institutions.department_or_unit: Department of Economics and Informatics, Faculty of Organization and Management

institutions.name: Silesian University of Technology
institutions.department_or_unit: Department of Production Engineering, Faculty of Organization and Management

related_research.title: Artificial Intelligence in Smart Cities—Applications, Barriers, and Future Directions: A Review
related_research.notes: Systematic review of AI applications and barriers in smart cities across six domains.

paraphrased_statement: An architectural critique of NEOM’s Cognitive City imagines a fully instrumented urban environment in which sensors, cameras and biometric systems feed a central AI operating system that optimizes transport, utilities, healthcare and daily services. The same vision, however, raises the prospect of an unprecedented surveillance infrastructure where every movement, transaction and interaction is tracked, potentially turning the city into a model of pervasive algorithmic control as much as an efficiency utopia.

source.source_title: NEOM's Cognitive City: Smart Utopia or Surveillance Dystopia?

quoted_persons.name: Maria Bogatinovska
quoted_persons.role: architectural designer; author of the essay

project_name: NEOM Cognitive City critical essay

related_research.title: NEOM's Cognitive City: Smart Utopia or Surveillance Dystopia?
related_research.notes: Architectural and ethical critique of NEOM’s cognitive-city vision, focusing on surveillance, data rights and human impacts.

paraphrased_statement: The Line is framed as the world’s first cognitive city that continuously predicts and reacts to residents’ needs using AI, sensors, data centers and autonomous systems, aiming to optimize services, cut emissions and deliver ultra-personalized urban life at scale.

source.source_title: The Line from NEOM
source.source_organization: Jacobs Urban Tech Hub, Cornell Tech

project_name: The Line cognitive city case study

originators.name: Yixuan Wang
originators.organization: Jacobs Urban Tech Hub, Cornell Tech

institutions.name: Jacobs Urban Tech Hub, Cornell Tech

related_research.title: NEOM’S The Line: The world’s first cognitive city
related_research.notes: Media feature describing The Line as a cognitive city that uses AI to predict and respond to residents’ needs.

related_research.title: Seven Years of Saudi Arabia’s NEOM Project: Prospects and Challenges
related_research.notes: Policy analysis discussing NEOM’s strategic ambitions, financing and geopolitical implications.

paraphrased_statement: Urban digital twins are envisioned as AI-augmented virtual replicas of cities where generative AI continuously expands and refines urban data, scenarios, and 3D models, enabling autonomous simulations, participatory planning, and human-AI co-design of future neighbourhoods.

source.source_title: Leveraging generative AI for urban digital twins: a scoping review on the autonomous generation of urban data, scenarios, designs, and 3D city models for smart city advancement

project_name: Generative AI for urban digital twins

related_research.title: Generative Artificial Intelligence in the Context of Urban Spaces
related_research.notes: Explores generative AI applications for urban space design and planning.

paraphrased_statement: Future cities are imagined as ecosystems where AI, blockchain and digital twins form an interdependent trinity: AI interprets real-time urban data, digital twins mirror and simulate the city, and blockchain anchors transactions and data flows in a trusted, decentralized ledger to support more responsive, transparent and inclusive urban governance.

source.source_title: The Urban Trinity: AI + Blockchain + Digital Twins = Future City?

project_name: Urban Trinity future city vision

paraphrased_statement: The Riyadh Digital Twin is presented as a large-scale, photorealistic urban twin that acts simultaneously as planning instrument, investment showcase and citizen engagement platform, allowing stakeholders to navigate future districts, test scenarios and discuss projects through immersive, game-engine-based interfaces.

source.source_title: From Vision to Reality: Using Digital Twin Technology in Urban Planning to Engage Citizens and Shape Future Cities

project_name: Riyadh Digital Twin

paraphrased_statement: The Line is interpreted as a radical linear prototype that compresses urban life into a 500-metre-high corridor promising zero emissions and AI-powered efficiency, while at the same time raising questions about surveillance, social stratification and ecological disruption in a sealed, top-down planned environment.

source.source_title: The Line as a Radical Urban Prototype for Smart and Disruptive City Planning

project_name: The Line radical prototype critique

paraphrased_statement: Dubai Live is envisioned as an AI-powered, real-time command hub that fuses digital twin representations of the city with predictive analytics to orchestrate urban operations, from infrastructure and inspections to waste management, as part of a broader ambition to govern the city through integrated, data-driven systems.

source.source_title: Dubai unveils 'Dubai Live': An AI-powered command hub to digitally govern the city in real time

project_name: Dubai Live AI city command hub

paraphrased_statement: Urban digital twins are combined with immersive metaverse environments so that planners, citizens and businesses can enter a shared, data-rich 3D version of the city, compare alternative futures and negotiate trade-offs before committing to physical change.

source.source_title: Urban digital twins and the metaverse

project_name: Urban Digital Twins & Metaverses

paraphrased_statement: Metaverse platforms and city-scale digital twins are framed as complementary layers: digital twins maintain accurate, analytical models of urban systems, while metaverse front-ends turn these models into explorable, social and experiential spaces for decision-making.

source.source_title: Metaverse and Digital Twins in the age of AI and XR

project_name: Metaverse and Digital Twins in the age of AI and XR

paraphrased_statement: The urban metaverse is described as an immersive 3D interface layer sitting on top of city data platforms and digital twins, where citizens, planners and officials meet as avatars to explore policies, simulate crises and collaboratively design street-level interventions.

source.source_title: Urban Metaverse: Applications, Challenges, and Research Opportunities

project_name: Urban Metaverse for immersive city governance

paraphrased_statement: The MetaOmniCity concept imagines an urban metaverse ecosystem in which multiple city digital twins and service platforms are integrated into a persistent virtual environment that people can access across devices, turning the city into a network of shared immersive experiences.

source.source_title: MetaOmniCity: An Urban Metaverse Ecosystem Conceptual Framework

project_name: MetaOmniCity urban metaverse ecosystem

paraphrased_statement: Large language model agents are proposed as natural-language interfaces to complex smart city systems, allowing officials, citizens and operators to ask questions, request analyses and trigger workflows in plain language, while specialised agents coordinate tasks in the background.

source.source_title: Large Language Model Agents for Smart City Management

project_name: LLM agents for smart city management

paraphrased_statement: Agentic urban AI is envisioned as a layer of software agents that autonomously monitor urban indicators, negotiate with one another and propose coordinated interventions, shifting cities from centrally programmed systems to self-organising, goal-seeking urban ecologies.

source.source_title: Agentic Urban AI: Towards Self-organising Cities

project_name: Agentic urban AI for self-organising cities

paraphrased_statement: Generative AI and multi-agent systems are used to simulate thousands of mobility scenarios in parallel, coordinating fleets, public transport and micro-mobility in near real time, with personalised route suggestions emerging from continuous citywide optimisation.

source.source_title: A Generative AI Based Multi-agent Framework for Smart Urban Mobility

project_name: GenAI-powered multi-agent smart urban mobility

paraphrased_statement: A new wave of smart city applications is envisioned as networks of specialised AI agents that collaboratively manage energy, mobility, public safety and disaster response, treating the city as an interconnected system rather than separate service silos.

source.source_title: The Next Generation of Multi-Agent Smart City Applications

project_name: Next generation multi-agent smart city applications

paraphrased_statement: Digital-first modelling is described as a planning paradigm in which city projects are first developed, tested and negotiated in immersive, data-rich virtual environments before construction, making the urban metaverse a primary workspace for planners, engineers and communities.

source.source_title: 2025 Trend Report: Digital-first Modelling and the Urban Metaverse

project_name: Digital-first modelling and the urban metaverse

paraphrased_statement: NEOM is described as a multi-layered AI-powered cognitive city project in which AI, digital twins, renewable energy and advanced mobility systems are tightly integrated to position the region as a global testbed for future urban living and innovation-driven economies.

source.source_title: NEOM: Saudi Arabia’s $500 Billion AI-powered Future City

project_name: NEOM AI-powered cognitive city overview
